<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp005" view="all">Preferential azido bridging have resulted dinuclear and polynuclear Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> and Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Schiff base complexes. We report first singly μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridged square planar Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Schiff base dimer exhibiting unusually strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction and the high turnover numbers obtained for the Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup>–Schiff base–PhIO system precedes the catalytic activity of other cobalt catalysts for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase.<ce:display>

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Preferential azido bridging have resulted dinuclear and polynuclear CoIII and CuII-Schiff base complexes. We report first singly μ1,3-N3 bridged square planar CuII-Schiff base dimer exhibiting unusually strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction and the high turnover numbers obtained for the CoIII-Schiff base-PhIO system precedes the catalytic activity of other cobalt catalysts for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase.

Highlights

► Azide ions regulate the geometry of the complexes. ► Highest magnitude of J =-252(1)cm-1 was obtained for singly μ1,3-N3 bridged CuII-Schiff base complex. ► CoIII-Schiff base-PhIO system in alkene oxidation results abnormally high t.o.n.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp015" view="all">A tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand [(1<ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>,3<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>)-3-((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)-1-phenylbut-1-en-1-ol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>] in presence of azide ions coordinates with cobalt(II) and copper(II) ions giving rise to three new coordination complexes [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]·ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(μ-O<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). The complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, UV–Vis spectral studies, and single crystal X-ray diffraction studies. These complexes demonstrate that under different synthetic conditions the azide ions and the Schiff base ligand (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) show different coordination modes with cobalt(II) and copper(II) ions, giving rise to unusual dinuclear and polynuclear species (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) whose structural variations are discussed. Magneto-structural correlation for the very rare singly μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridged Cu<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>–Schiff base dinuclear species (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) has been studied. In addition, the catalytic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for alkene oxidation and the general catalase-like activity behavior of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have been discussed.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand [(1Z,3E)-3-((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)-1-phenylbut-1-en-1-ol= LH] in presence of azide ions coordinates with cobalt(II) and copper(II) ions giving rise to three new coordination complexes [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1), [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)]⋅ClO4 (2) and [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3). The complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, UV-Vis spectral studies, and single crystal X-ray diffraction studies. These complexes demonstrate that under different synthetic conditions the azide ions and the Schiff base ligand (LH) show different coordination modes with cobalt(II) and copper(II) ions, giving rise to unusual dinuclear and polynuclear species (1, 2 and 3) whose structural variations are discussed. Magneto-structural correlation for the very rare singly μ1,3-N3 bridged CuII-Schiff base dinuclear species (2) has been studied. In addition, the catalytic properties of 1 for alkene oxidation and the general catalase-like activity behavior of 2 have been discussed.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">The major task in designing pseudohalide bridged compounds depends on the proper choice of the bridging ligands as well as the stereochemical environment surrounding the paramagnetic centers. The azide ion has been shown to be able to link two or more metal ions in various modes: where μ-1,1 (<ce:italic>end-on</ce:italic>, EO) and μ-1,3 (<ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic>, EE) are the usual modes but not the only, since other modes, including μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-1,1,1 , μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-1,1,1,1 , μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-1,1,3 , or the very rare μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-1,1,3,3  modes have also been observed. The azide ligand has been a prominent actor in the development of molecular magnetism since its inception . Primarily, this group has acted as a structural bridge and magnetic coupler of paramagnetic metal ions within one-, two- or three-dimensional extended coordination arrays, rather than discrete molecules, unveiling interesting phenomena such as ferrimagnetism within homometallic chains , or sheets .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The major task in designing pseudohalide bridged compounds depends on the proper choice of the bridging ligands as well as the stereochemical environment surrounding the paramagnetic centers. The azide ion has been shown to be able to link two or more metal ions in various modes: where μ-1,1 (end-on, EO) and μ-1,3 (end-to-end, EE) are the usual modes but not the only, since other modes, including μ3-1,1,1 , μ4-1,1,1,1 , μ3-1,1,3 , or the very rare μ4-1,1,3,3  modes have also been observed. The azide ligand has been a prominent actor in the development of molecular magnetism since its inception . Primarily, this group has acted as a structural bridge and magnetic coupler of paramagnetic metal ions within one-, two- or three-dimensional extended coordination arrays, rather than discrete molecules, unveiling interesting phenomena such as ferrimagnetism within homometallic chains , or sheets .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Regarding the magnetic coupling, it is well known that azide ions with a symmetric μ-1,1 (<ce:italic>end-on</ce:italic>, EO) coordination mode, give rise to ferromagnetic coupling as far as the Cu–N–Cu angle does not exceeds ca. 104° . On the other hand, for the symmetric μ-1,3 (<ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic>, EE) coordination mode, the magnetic coupling is strong and antiferromagnetic . Interestingly, for asymmetric azide bridges, the coupling is weak and antiferromagnetic except for the EE coordination mode with a long Cu–N bond distance that may give rise to a weak ferromagnetic coupling . The huge number of azide cooper(II) complexes  have lead to several theoretical and magneto-structural correlations where different structural parameters as (i) the Cu–N bond distances, (ii) the Cu–N–Cu bond angles, (iii) the asymmetry of the bridge and (iv) the torsion angle in the central Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> entity have been considered .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Regarding the magnetic coupling, it is well known that azide ions with a symmetric μ-1,1 (end-on, EO) coordination mode, give rise to ferromagnetic coupling as far as the Cu-N-Cu angle does not exceeds ca. 104° . On the other hand, for the symmetric μ-1,3 (end-to-end, EE) coordination mode, the magnetic coupling is strong and antiferromagnetic . Interestingly, for asymmetric azide bridges, the coupling is weak and antiferromagnetic except for the EE coordination mode with a long Cu-N bond distance that may give rise to a weak ferromagnetic coupling . The huge number of azide cooper(II) complexes  have lead to several theoretical and magneto-structural correlations where different structural parameters as (i) the Cu-N bond distances, (ii) the Cu-N-Cu bond angles, (iii) the asymmetry of the bridge and (iv) the torsion angle in the central Cu2N2 entity have been considered .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Unlike the doubly <ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic> azido bridged copper(II) dinuclear species, singly <ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic> azido bridged copper(II) dinuclear complexes are still very rare . In theses rare examples the coupling is much weaker than in the doubly <ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic> azido bridge copper(II) complexes, where antiferromagnetic interactions as strong as −105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> have been found .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Unlike the doubly end-to-end azido bridged copper(II) dinuclear species, singly end-to-end azido bridged copper(II) dinuclear complexes are still very rare . In theses rare examples the coupling is much weaker than in the doubly end-to-end azido bridge copper(II) complexes, where antiferromagnetic interactions as strong as -105cm-1 have been found .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Many Schiff base complexes of metal ions show high catalytic activity. The oxidation of hydrocarbons using Schiff base complexes has been a field of academic and industrial interest to analyze the catalytic activity of various metal complexes . The ring opening of large cycloalkanes is usually a difficult process but Schiff base complexes of cobalt(II)  and chromium(III)  were effective in these reactions with significant enantioselectivity. The manganese(II) complexes of bis(2-pyridinaldehyde)-ethylenediamine and bis(2-pyridinaldehyde)-propylenediamine ligands have been used in epoxidation of olefins but reasonable epoxide selectivity was possible only in the presence of PhIO oxidant . The extent of olefins epoxidation was dependent on OH substitution on the Schiff base ligand. The enantioselective epoxidation of styrene, indene and 2,2-dimethyl-6-nitro chromene has been carried out using dicationic chiral manganese(III) salen complexes . It has also been found that the epoxidation of styrene to styrene oxide with yields as high as 96% has been achieved by poly-(vinylbenzyl)acetylacetonate complexes of cobalt(II) or manganese(II) in the presence of isobutyraldehyde under an atmospheric pressure of molecular oxygen at room temperature . Interestingly no other azido-bridged dicobalt complex has been tested previously for alkene oxidation. Besides, most cobalt complexes previously tested for the oxidation of alkenes with several oxidants, required large amounts of catalyst and afforded low t.o.n. In this sense, the study of the catalytic activity of new cobalt complexes<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>with different topology and ligands provides some clues for the design of more efficient catalysts.</ce:para>

The manganese(II) complexes of bis(2-pyridinaldehyde)-ethylenediamine and bis(2-pyridinaldehyde)-propylenediamine ligands have been used in epoxidation of olefins but reasonable epoxide selectivity was possible only in the presence of PhIO oxidant . The extent of olefins epoxidation was dependent on OH substitution on the Schiff base ligand. The enantioselective epoxidation of styrene, indene and 2,2-dimethyl-6-nitro chromene has been carried out using dicationic chiral manganese(III) salen complexes . It has also been found that the epoxidation of styrene to styrene oxide with yields as high as 96% has been achieved by poly-(vinylbenzyl)acetylacetonate complexes of cobalt(II) or manganese(II) in the presence of isobutyraldehyde under an atmospheric pressure of molecular oxygen at room temperature . Interestingly no other azido-bridged dicobalt complex has been tested previously for alkene oxidation. Besides, most cobalt complexes previously tested for the oxidation of alkenes with several oxidants, required large amounts of catalyst and afforded low t.o.n. elements.clean_text: Recently, the reactivity of both homo- and hetero-polynuclear copper(II)-Schiff base complexes for H2O2 disproportionation, as a functional model for Mn-CAT has been investigated . Catalase, one of the three major sensitive protective enzymes in living organisms, exists in almost all aerobically respiring organisms. It protects cells from the toxic effects of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), the latter being linked to a variety of pathological consequences such as aging, diabetes and cancer . On the other hand hydrogen peroxide is a ubiquitous metabolite in living systems, produced at increased levels in a variety of pathological situations. All living cells have devised a sophisticated machinery to suppress or at least control H2O2 production. The catalase enzymes which are able to disproportionate H2O2 into less harmful dioxygen and water are an important part of this machinery (Eq. ). elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The HO<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>
</ce:sup>/HOO<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>
</ce:sup> radical formation induces lipid peroxidation, membrane damage, and cell death . In normal conditions, the organism protects itself against hydrogen peroxide using the catalase enzyme. However, when a stress occurs, the natural defenses are insufficient . Because the natural enzyme cannot be used as a drug due to its instability in solution and to delivery problems, synthetic compounds able to dismutate hydrogen peroxide have been designed and studied .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The HO  /HOO   radical formation induces lipid peroxidation, membrane damage, and cell death . In normal conditions, the organism protects itself against hydrogen peroxide using the catalase enzyme. However, when a stress occurs, the natural defenses are insufficient . Because the natural enzyme cannot be used as a drug due to its instability in solution and to delivery problems, synthetic compounds able to dismutate hydrogen peroxide have been designed and studied .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In this paper we present three new azido complexes [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)].ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(μ-O<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), exhibiting the μ-1,1 (<ce:italic>end-on</ce:italic>, EO), μ-1,3 (<ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic>, EE) and the unprecedented μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-1,1,1 coordination modes of azide ions with a tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) . Single crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (brown needle-shaped crystals) is a symmetrical double μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-azido bridged cobalt(III) dinuclear complex whereas <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (brown prismatic crystals) is a unique copper(II) dimer with a single symmetric μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-azido bridge. By changing the molar ratio of the copper salt, the Schiff base ligand (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) and the azide ion we have also obtained a dark blue amorphous product in much lower yield (compared to that of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) whose recrystallisation yielded a few blue needle-shaped single crystals of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The X-ray diffraction study of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> shows the presence of enolato bridges along with μ-1,1 and the rare μ<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>-1,1,1 bridging modes of azide ions resulting in the formation of a new copper(II) coordination polymer, composed of vertex shared dicubanes with a vacant vertex. All the complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, UV–Vis spectroscopies. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement was performed only for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> since <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is diamagnetic (dinuclear Co<ce:sup loc="post">III</ce:sup> species) and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was obtained in a much lower yield even after several attempts of its synthesis. Finally, we have also measured the catalytic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for alkene oxidations and the general catalase-like activity behavior for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this paper we present three new azido complexes [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1), [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)].ClO4 (2) and [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3), exhibiting the μ-1,1 (end-on, EO), μ-1,3 (end-to-end, EE) and the unprecedented μ3-1,1,1 coordination modes of azide ions with a tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand (LH) . Single crystal X-ray diffraction study revealed that, 1 (brown needle-shaped crystals) is a symmetrical double μ1,1-azido bridged cobalt(III) dinuclear complex whereas 2 (brown prismatic crystals) is a unique copper(II) dimer with a single symmetric μ1,3-azido bridge. By changing the molar ratio of the copper salt, the Schiff base ligand (LH) and the azide ion we have also obtained a dark blue amorphous product in much lower yield (compared to that of 2) whose recrystallisation yielded a few blue needle-shaped single crystals of 3. The X-ray diffraction study of 3 shows the presence of enolato bridges along with μ-1,1 and the rare μ3-1,1,1 bridging modes of azide ions resulting in the formation of a new copper(II) coordination polymer, composed of vertex shared dicubanes with a vacant vertex. All the complexes were characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, UV-Vis spectroscopies. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement was performed only for 2 since 1 is diamagnetic (dinuclear CoIII species) and 3 was obtained in a much lower yield even after several attempts of its synthesis. Finally, we have also measured the catalytic properties of 1 for alkene oxidations and the general catalase-like activity behavior for 2.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Benzoylacetone and 2-picolylamine were purchased form Aldrich Chemical Company. Sodium azide was purchased from Fluka and were used as received. Cobalt perchlorate hexahydrate and copper perchlorate hexahydrate were prepared by treatment of the respective metal carbonates (cobalt carbonate and copper carbonate (E. Merck, India)) with 60% perchloric acid (E. Merck, India) followed by the slow evaporation on a steam bath. Thereafter filtered through a fine glass-frit and were preserved in a CaCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> desiccator for further use. Styrene, <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-stylbene, cyclohexene, <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-4-octene, <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-chloroperbenzoic acid (<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA), <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-methylmorpholine <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-oxide (NMO) and 4-phenyl pyridine <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-oxide (PNO) used in the catalytic experiments were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. Dichloromethane, acetonitrile and acetone were of HPLC grade (Merk). Iodosylbenzene (PhIO) was synthesized using reported procedures by hydrolysis of iodobenzene diacetate with a solution of sodium hydroxide . Styrene oxide and benzaldehyde used to obtain HPLC calibration curves were purchased from Aldrich. The concentration of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> stock solution was determined by iodometric titration. O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> saturated Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> or CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN solutions were used for oxidation assays where O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was the oxygen source.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials

Benzoylacetone and 2-picolylamine were purchased form Aldrich Chemical Company. Sodium azide was purchased from Fluka and were used as received. Cobalt perchlorate hexahydrate and copper perchlorate hexahydrate were prepared by treatment of the respective metal carbonates (cobalt carbonate and copper carbonate (E. Merck, India)) with 60% perchloric acid (E. Merck, India) followed by the slow evaporation on a steam bath. Thereafter filtered through a fine glass-frit and were preserved in a CaCl2 desiccator for further use. Styrene, cis-stylbene, cyclohexene, trans-4-octene, m-chloroperbenzoic acid (m-CPBA), N-methylmorpholine N-oxide (NMO) and 4-phenyl pyridine N-oxide (PNO) used in the catalytic experiments were purchased from Aldrich and used as received. Dichloromethane, acetonitrile and acetone were of HPLC grade (Merk). Iodosylbenzene (PhIO) was synthesized using reported procedures by hydrolysis of iodobenzene diacetate with a solution of sodium hydroxide . Styrene oxide and benzaldehyde used to obtain HPLC calibration curves were purchased from Aldrich. The concentration of H2O2 stock solution was determined by iodometric titration. O2 saturated Cl2CH2 or CH3CN solutions were used for oxidation assays where O2 was the oxygen source.

The electronic spectra of the ligand and complexes were recorded at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K on a Perkin–Elmer <ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> – 40 UV–Vis-spectrometer using HPLC grade acetonitrile as solvent with a 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm quartz cuvette in the range 200–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. C, H, N microanalyses of the ligand and the complexes were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 II elemental analyser. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2–300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K with an applied magnetic field of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>T on a polycrystalline sample of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holders previously measured using the same conditions and for the diamagnetic contributions of the salt as deduced by using Pascal’s constant tables. HPLC experiments were performed with a Varian ProStar chromatograph equipped with DAD 335 detector using a Varian Microsorb-MV 100-5 C18 column (250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>4.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mm), thermostated with a Zeltec heater. Samples were eluted with a 70:30 acetonitrile:methanol mixture at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and a flow rate of 0.4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL/min. Under these experimental conditions, retention times (<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text:
Physical measurements

The Fourier Transform Infrared spectra (4000-400cm-1) of the ligand and the complexes were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrophotometer RX I FT-IR system as solid KBr pellets. The electronic spectra of the ligand and complexes were recorded at 300K on a Perkin-Elmer λ - 40 UV-Vis-spectrometer using HPLC grade acetonitrile as solvent with a 1cm quartz cuvette in the range 200-800nm. C, H, N microanalyses of the ligand and the complexes were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 2400 II elemental analyser. The magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out in the temperature range 2-300K with an applied magnetic field of 0.1T on a polycrystalline sample of 2 with a Quantum Design MPMS-XL-5 SQUID magnetometer. The susceptibility data were corrected for the sample holders previously measured using the same conditions and for the diamagnetic contributions of the salt as deduced by using Pascal's constant tables. HPLC experiments were performed with a Varian ProStar chromatograph equipped with DAD 335 detector using a Varian Microsorb-MV 100-5 C18 column (250×4.6mm), thermostated with a Zeltec heater. Samples were eluted with a 70:30 acetonitrile:methanol mixture at 40°C and a flow rate of 0.4mL/min. Under these experimental conditions, retention times (R t) were: styrene (R t =7.92min), styrene epoxide (R t =7.21min), benzaldehyde (R t =7.05min), cis-stylbene (R t =8.51min), cyclohexene (R t =9.47min), trans-4-octene (R t =11.39min), m-chloroperbenzoic acid (R t =7.20min) and iodosylbenzene (R t =8.45min). Calibration curves were used to quantify the alkene conversion and product selectivity. At least two independent experiments were performed for each reaction condition. Blank experiments with each oxidant and using the same experimental conditions except catalyst were performed. In every case, alkene conversion was null (PhIO+alkene reaction) or much slower than in the presence of the complex.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis of [C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>C(OH)<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>CHC(CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>NCH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>N] (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">The synthesis and characterization of the Schiff base ligand (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) has been done following the method described in the literature . The 1:1 equimolar condensation of 2-picolylamine and benzoylacetone for 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h in methanolic medium results in a yellow solution. The color indicates the formation of the Schiff base ligand (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) which was used without further purification. Yield: 0.221<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (88%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for [C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O]: C, 76.19; H, 6.35; N, 11.11. Found: C, 76.18; H, 6.31; N, 11.10%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of [C6H5C(OH)CHC(CH3)NCH2C5H4N] (LH)

The synthesis and characterization of the Schiff base ligand (LH) has been done following the method described in the literature . The 1:1 equimolar condensation of 2-picolylamine and benzoylacetone for 2h in methanolic medium results in a yellow solution. The color indicates the formation of the Schiff base ligand (LH) which was used without further purification. Yield: 0.221g (88%). Anal. Calc. for [C16H16N2O]: C, 76.19; H, 6.35; N, 11.11. Found: C, 76.18; H, 6.31; N, 11.10%.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0055" view="all">
<ce:bold>Caution!</ce:bold> Perchlorate salts and azide derivatives in presence of organic ligands are potentially explosive and should be used in small quantity with much care.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Syntheses of [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">The slow addition of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of a yellow methanolic solution of the Schiff base (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) (0.252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) to 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of a methanolic solution of cobalt perchlorate hexahydrate (0.365<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) resulted in a dark red solution. This solution was stirred for 15<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at room temperature and then followed by the addition of 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of an aqueous solution of sodium azide (0.130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol). The dark red solution so obtained was gently stirred for 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h at 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, resulting in a color change from dark red to dark brown. The dark brown solution was then filtered and kept at room temperature. Brown needle shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction was obtained after one day. The crystals were filtered and air-dried. Yield: 0.314<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (86%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for [C<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf> Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]: C, 48.69; H, 3.80; N, 28.40. Found: C, 48.62; H, 3.77; N, 28.38%.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Caution! Perchlorate salts and azide derivatives in presence of organic ligands are potentially explosive and should be used in small quantity with much care.

Syntheses of [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1)

The slow addition of 20mL of a yellow methanolic solution of the Schiff base (LH) (0.252g, 1mmol) to 10mL of a methanolic solution of cobalt perchlorate hexahydrate (0.365g, 1mmol) resulted in a dark red solution. This solution was stirred for 15min at room temperature and then followed by the addition of 2mL of an aqueous solution of sodium azide (0.130g, 2mmol). The dark red solution so obtained was gently stirred for 1h at 40°C, resulting in a color change from dark red to dark brown. The dark brown solution was then filtered and kept at room temperature. Brown needle shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction was obtained after one day. The crystals were filtered and air-dried. Yield: 0.314g (86%). Anal. Calc. for [C32H30 Co2N16O2]: C, 48.69; H, 3.80; N, 28.40. Found: C, 48.62; H, 3.77; N, 28.38%.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Syntheses of [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)]·ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (0.37<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of methanol by stirring. It was then followed by the subsequent addition of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of a yellow methanolic solution of <ce:bold>LH</ce:bold> (0.252<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) resulting in a light green solution. While the solution was stirred, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of an aqueous methanolic solution of sodium azide (0.032<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were carefully added dropwise to the light green solution to give a dark green solution. Addition of sodium azide was immediately stopped when a small amount of brown colored solid separated. The dark green solution was then filtered and kept in a refrigerator. Brown prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after three days. Crystals were filtered and air-dried. Yield: 0.303<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (82%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for [C<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>]: C, 49.79; H, 3.89; N, 12.70. Found: C, 49.78; H, 3.85; N, 12.68%.</ce:para>

Syntheses of [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)]⋅ClO4 (2)

Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (0.37g, 1mmol) was dissolved in 10mL of methanol by stirring. It was then followed by the subsequent addition of 20mL of a yellow methanolic solution of LH (0.252g, 1mmol) resulting in a light green solution. While the solution was stirred, 5mL of an aqueous methanolic solution of sodium azide (0.032g, 0.5mmol) were carefully added dropwise to the light green solution to give a dark green solution. Addition of sodium azide was immediately stopped when a small amount of brown colored solid separated. The dark green solution was then filtered and kept in a refrigerator. Brown prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after three days. Crystals were filtered and air-dried. Yield: 0.303g (82%). Anal. Calc. for [C32H30Cl1Cu2N7O6]: C, 49.79; H, 3.89; N, 12.70. Found: C, 49.78; H, 3.85; N, 12.68%.

<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (0.55<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) was dissolved in 1:1 v/v methanol–acetone mixture (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) by vigorous stirring. 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of a yellow methanolic solution of the Schiff base (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) (0.126<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were slowly added with stirring to the copper perchlorate hexahydrate solution to produce a bluish green solution. Successive very slow addition of 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of an aqueous solution of sodium azide (0.192<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) at higher molar ratio compared to that of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, prevented the precipitation of a brown solid and resulted in a dark green solution that produced a small amount of green solid which redissolved upon complete addition of sodium azide. The obtained dark green solution was then filtered and was kept at room temperature. A dark blue amorphous product was obtained in a much lower yield (compared to that of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) after a week. Recrystallisation of the dark blue product in 1:1 v/v methanol–acetonitrile mixture resulted in a few blue needle shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction after two weeks. Crystals were filtrated and air-dried. The IR spectra of the amorphous and the crystalline product were almost similar to each other but were not superimposable. Yield: 0.165<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (30%). <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calc. for [C<ce:inf loc="post">32</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">30</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">28</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]: C, 33.20; H, 2.59; N, 33.89. Found: C, 33.18; H, 2.53; N, 33.86%.</ce:para>

Syntheses of [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3)

Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (0.55g, 1.5mmol) was dissolved in 1:1 v/v methanol-acetone mixture (20mL) by vigorous stirring. 10mL of a yellow methanolic solution of the Schiff base (LH) (0.126g, 0.5mmol) were slowly added with stirring to the copper perchlorate hexahydrate solution to produce a bluish green solution. Successive very slow addition of 5mL of an aqueous solution of sodium azide (0.192g, 3mmol) at higher molar ratio compared to that of 2, prevented the precipitation of a brown solid and resulted in a dark green solution that produced a small amount of green solid which redissolved upon complete addition of sodium azide. The obtained dark green solution was then filtered and was kept at room temperature. A dark blue amorphous product was obtained in a much lower yield (compared to that of 2) after a week. Recrystallisation of the dark blue product in 1:1 v/v methanol-acetonitrile mixture resulted in a few blue needle shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction after two weeks. Crystals were filtrated and air-dried. The IR spectra of the amorphous and the crystalline product were almost similar to each other but were not superimposable. Yield: 0.165g (30%). Anal. Calc. for [C32H30Cu5N28O2]: C, 33.20; H, 2.59; N, 33.89. Found: C, 33.18; H, 2.53; N, 33.86%.

<ce:section-title>Crystallographic data collections and structure determinations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0075" view="all">The crystal structure analyses of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were performed using three different X-ray diffractometers. The equipment used for each sample is listed with the crystallographic data and the refinement results in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>. Single crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were coated in Paratone-N heavy oil and mounted in a Cryoloop before being transferred to the cold stream on the respective diffractometers. The structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> has been solved by direct methods using the SIR92 program  combined to fourier difference syntheses and refined against <ce:italic>F</ce:italic> using reflections with [<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>><ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>)] with <ce:small-caps>crystals</ce:small-caps> program . The H atoms for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> were all located in a difference map, but those attached to carbon atoms were repositioned geometrically. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> a semi-empirical absorption correction <ce:small-caps>multiscan</ce:small-caps> program  has been applied to the data sets. Structure solution and refinement have been performed by using <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps>-97 and <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>-97 programs . For <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> data collection, reduction and absorption corrections were done with the <ce:small-caps>apex</ce:small-caps>2 suite of programs . All non hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in calculated positions to correspond to standard bond lengths and angles.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic data collections and structure determinations

The crystal structure analyses of 1, 2 and 3 were performed using three different X-ray diffractometers. The equipment used for each sample is listed with the crystallographic data and the refinement results in  . Single crystals of 1, 2 and 3 were coated in Paratone-N heavy oil and mounted in a Cryoloop before being transferred to the cold stream on the respective diffractometers. The structure of 1 has been solved by direct methods using the SIR92 program  combined to fourier difference syntheses and refined against F using reflections with [I >2σ(I)] with crystals program . The H atoms for 1 were all located in a difference map, but those attached to carbon atoms were repositioned geometrically. For 2 a semi-empirical absorption correction multiscan program  has been applied to the data sets. Structure solution and refinement have been performed by using shelxs-97 and shelxl-97 programs . For 3 data collection, reduction and absorption corrections were done with the apex2 suite of programs . All non hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. All hydrogen atoms were located in calculated positions to correspond to standard bond lengths and angles.

<ce:section-title>Catalysis experiments</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Procedure for alkene oxidations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0080" view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μmol (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol%) and 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μmol (4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol%)) and an olefin substrate (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) were dissolved in freshly distilled specified solvent (CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN or acetone). With stirring and at a controlled temperature the oxidant (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol in oxidation with PhIO and <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol in oxidation with aqueous 30% H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> saturated solution with dioxygen) was added. Then the reaction was stirred at constant temperature and the reaction time for maximal conversion was determined by withdrawing periodically aliquots of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL from the reaction mixture. This time was used to monitor the efficiency of the catalyst. Parallel experiments were carried out by dissolving a neutral donor ligand (NMO and PNO, 0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) together with <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>+<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>alkene. Aliquots were diluted with 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of acetonitrile and filtered through a 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μm membrane prior to injection into the chromatograph.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalysis experiments

Procedure for alkene oxidations

Complex 1 (1μmol (0.2mol%) and 20μmol (4mol%)) and an olefin substrate (0.5mmol) were dissolved in freshly distilled specified solvent (CH2Cl2, CH3CN or acetone). With stirring and at a controlled temperature the oxidant (1mmol in oxidation with PhIO and m-CPBA, 5mmol in oxidation with aqueous 30% H2O2, and O2 saturated solution with dioxygen) was added. Then the reaction was stirred at constant temperature and the reaction time for maximal conversion was determined by withdrawing periodically aliquots of 20μL from the reaction mixture. This time was used to monitor the efficiency of the catalyst. Parallel experiments were carried out by dissolving a neutral donor ligand (NMO and PNO, 0.5mmol) together with 1 +alkene. Aliquots were diluted with 2mL of acetonitrile and filtered through a 0.2μm membrane prior to injection into the chromatograph.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Procedure for catalase-like activity</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0085" view="all">Volumetric measurements of evolved dioxygen during the reactions of the dinuclear copper(II) complex (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> were carried out as follows:</ce:para><ce:para id="p0090" view="all">A 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup> three-necked round-bottom flask containing a DMF solution of the complex (2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM) was placed in a water bath (25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C). One of the necks was connected to a burette and the others were stoppered by a rubber septum. While the solution was stirring, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 3.08<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M) was injected into it through the rubber septum using a microsyringe. Volumes of evolved dioxygen were measured at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min time intervals by volumetry. In cases where imidazole, 1-methylimidazole or pyridine (0.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) was added this was introduced into the reaction vessel before the addition of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (in the absence of the base the complex was either inactive or very weak catalysts for this reaction).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Procedure for catalase-like activity

Volumetric measurements of evolved dioxygen during the reactions of the dinuclear copper(II) complex (2) with H2O2 were carried out as follows:

A 50cm3 three-necked round-bottom flask containing a DMF solution of the complex (2mL, 1mM) was placed in a water bath (25°C). One of the necks was connected to a burette and the others were stoppered by a rubber septum. While the solution was stirring, H2O2 (0.5mL, 3.08M) was injected into it through the rubber septum using a microsyringe. Volumes of evolved dioxygen were measured at 1min time intervals by volumetry. In cases where imidazole, 1-methylimidazole or pyridine (0.5mL) was added this was introduced into the reaction vessel before the addition of H2O2 (in the absence of the base the complex was either inactive or very weak catalysts for this reaction).

Preparation of the haemolysate was done as described by Ninfali .</ce:para><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">CAT activity was determined with the following procedure. 40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL of the haemolysate was added to a tube containing 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL of sodium phosphate buffer saline (PBS, 0.01<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M, pH 7.4), and 1000<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL of 9.7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (dissolved in sodium phosphate buffer) and 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>μL of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM) was added to start the reaction. Evolved dioxygen (mL) was recorded following the reduction of hydrogen peroxide during 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min by volumetry. All statistical analyses were performed using Statistica software release 6.0. Analysis of variance was performed and means were separated using Fisher’s protected least significant differences (LSD) test at <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>≤<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.05.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the haemolysate

Blood from different five human collected in EDTA (20-25years old healthy male) was centrifuged (15min, 2500g). Preparation of the haemolysate was done as described by Ninfali .

CAT activity was determined with the following procedure. 40μL of the haemolysate was added to a tube containing 1000μL of sodium phosphate buffer saline (PBS, 0.01M, pH 7.4), and 1000μL of 9.7M H2O2 (dissolved in sodium phosphate buffer) and 20μL of 2 (1mM) was added to start the reaction. Evolved dioxygen (mL) was recorded following the reduction of hydrogen peroxide during 3min by volumetry. All statistical analyses were performed using Statistica software release 6.0. Analysis of variance was performed and means were separated using Fisher's protected least significant differences (LSD) test at P ≤0.05.

elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Fourier Transform IR spectroscopy

The IR spectra of 1, 2 and 3 have been analyzed in comparison with that of the free ligand LH in the region 4000-400cm-1. Although derived from the same Schiff base ligand (LH); the IR spectra of 1, 2 and 3 are quite different from one another except the characteristic IR bands for the azide ligand centered in the region 2022-2084cm-1 for all three complexes. In the spectra of 1, 2 and 3 well resolved sharp bands with a bifurcated peak at 2057, 2022 (1), 2078, 2068 (2) and 2084, 2050 (3)cm-1 are observed and assigned to ν N    N stretching of the azide moiety coordinated to different metal centers simultaneously . The characteristic imine stretching band at 1624cm-1 for LH has been considerably shifted to lower frequencies 1609 (1) and 1610 (2) and 1612 (3)cm-1 in the spectra of the complexes, and thereby clearly indicate coordination of the imine nitrogen with the metal centers in the respective complexes. Moreover, in the spectra of the complexes disappearance of the well defined band at 3412cm-1 for enolic OH stretching frequency (observed in the spectrum of the free ligand); clearly supports that on complexation the ligand (LH) undergoes deprotonation. The coordination of the deprotonated ligand to the metal centers in the respective complexes is also supported by the appearance of a strong CO absorption band at 1094 (1), 1060 (2) and 1054 (3)cm-1. The coordination of the heterocyclic nitrogen atom (pyridyl nitrogen of the deprotonated Schiff base ligand [L] - ) to the metal centers is evidenced by the low energy pyridine ring in-plane and out-of-plane vibrations in the spectrum of the LH (621 and 412cm-1), which in the spectra of the complexes shift to higher frequencies at 623, 641, 661 and 422, 430, 437cm-1, respectively . Unlike the spectra of 1 and 3 an additional characteristic strong bifurcated absorption band is observed in the region 1060-1124cm-1 for 2, indicates the presence of perchlorate anions in the complex. Finally the coordination of the nitrogen atom to the metal center is evidenced by the appearance of the sharp ν M    N bands obtained at 411 (1), 409 (2) and 406 (3)cm-1, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>UV–Vis spectroscopy</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0110" view="all">UV–Vis spectra of the ligand and the complexes (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) have been recorded at 300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K in HPLC grade acetonitrile solution but due to the poor solubility of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> in acetonitrile medium, solid state Nujol mull absorption electronic spectrum was recorded for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. It has been already reported earlier  that the spectra of the free ligand (<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>) shows two intraligand charge transfer (CT) bands at 331 and 248<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm whereas the spectra of all three complexes show three different CT bands at 450, 322, 266<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 402, 324, 258<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and 406, 328, 262<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>). Accordingly in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> the bands obtained at 322, 266<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, 324, 258<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm and 328, 262<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm are assigned to intraligand charge transfer transitions respectively but since the spectrum of the free ligand has no CT bands in the region 402–450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm hence we can conclude that CT bands obtained at 450, 402 and 406<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, respectively, are associated to L<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>→<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M charge transfer transitions. Besides these allowed bands, the three compounds also show much weaker and less well defined broad bands at 630<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), 600<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and 634 and 682<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) which are assigned to the d–d transitions in the respective complexes. The band at 630<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is attributed <ce:sup loc="pre">1</ce:sup>

elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis spectroscopy

UV-Vis spectra of the ligand and the complexes (1 and 2) have been recorded at 300K in HPLC grade acetonitrile solution but due to the poor solubility of 3 in acetonitrile medium, solid state Nujol mull absorption electronic spectrum was recorded for 3. It has been already reported earlier  that the spectra of the free ligand (LH) shows two intraligand charge transfer (CT) bands at 331 and 248nm whereas the spectra of all three complexes show three different CT bands at 450, 322, 266nm (1), 402, 324, 258nm (2) and 406, 328, 262nm (3). Accordingly in 1, 2 and 3 the bands obtained at 322, 266nm, 324, 258nm and 328, 262nm are assigned to intraligand charge transfer transitions respectively but since the spectrum of the free ligand has no CT bands in the region 402-450nm hence we can conclude that CT bands obtained at 450, 402 and 406nm in 1-3, respectively, are associated to L→M charge transfer transitions. Besides these allowed bands, the three compounds also show much weaker and less well defined broad bands at 630nm (1), 600nm (2) and 634 and 682nm (3) which are assigned to the d-d transitions in the respective complexes. The band at 630nm for 1 is attributed 1 A 1g → 1 T 1g transition for the distorted octahedral cobalt(III) ion, whereas d-d transition at 600nm for 2 is attributed to structurally well characterized square planar copper(II) complexes . Unlike 1 and 2, the two broad d-d bands obtained for 3 are in good agreement with the simultaneous presence of two different coordination environments in the complex. The band at 634nm is associated with a copper(II) center having a distorted octahedral geometry and the d-d transition at 682nm indicates the presence of copper(II) ions residing in a distorted square pyramidal geometry .

elements.clean_text:
Structural description of the complexes

[Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1)

Complex 1 is a centrosymmetric end-on azido bridged cobalt(III) dinuclear species with a Co(1)⋯Co(1) separation of 3.127Å ( ). The dinuclear unit is formed by two units of deprotonated NNO donor Schiff base ligands [L] - , two μ1,1-bridging azide ions and two terminally coordinated azide ions. The asymmetric unit forming the dinuclear unit is shown in  . Bond lengths and angles of 1 are listed in  . The cobalt center is six coordinated and presents a slightly distorted [CoN5O] octahedral geometry, mainly due to the coordination of the deprotonated NNO donor Schiff base ligand [L]- and three azide ions ().

The two axial sites of the cobalt(III) centers are occupied by two nitrogen atoms: an imine nitrogen, N(8), of the Schiff base ligand and the symmetry related N(31) atom of the second μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridge. Thus the two cobalt(III) centers of the dimer are connected by two μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridges that connect a basal position of one cobalt(III) ion with an axial position of the other and vice versa. The dimers are quite well isolated in the structure and do not present any H-bond ().</ce:para>

elements.clean_text:
[Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)]⋅ClO4 (2)

Unlike the cobalt complex (1), 2 is a singly μ1,3-N3 bridged copper(II) centro-symmetric dimer with the central N(4) atom of the μ1,3-N3 bridge located on an inversion center. The copper(II) centers in 2 are four-coordinate, exhibiting a slightly distorted square-planar geometry, and present a CuN3O environment formed by a pyridyl, N(1) and an imine nitrogen atom, N(2), both from [L] - , an azido nitrogen atom, N(3) of the μ1,3-bridging azide ligand and a deprotonated enolato oxygen atom, O(1) of [L] -  (in trans with the pyridyl N(1) atom,  ). The Cu-O bond distance is, as expected, shorter than the three Cu-N bond distances ( ). The overall N2OCu-N3-CuN2O centro-symmetric dinuclear unit is almost perfectly planar, with a maximum deviation of only 0.06Å from the average plane ( ). Furthermore, the complete dinuclear unit, including the Schiff base ligand, is also almost perfectly planar ( ). The charge neutrality of the complex [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)]+ is achieved by a perchlorate counter ion located between the planar dimeric monocationic units. As in 1, neither intra nor intermolecular H-bonding interactions are detected in 2.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0130" view="all">A search in the CCDC data base shows that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is the first singly μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridged symmetrical, four coordinated, copper(II)–Schiff base dinuclear species . The Cu(1)⋯Cu(1) separation in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 5.789<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and is shorter than that of the earlier reported copper(II) complexes with single μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridges (6.086(7)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  but is similar to those of other copper(II) complexes with μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3-</ce:inf>bridging cyanate (5.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) and thiocyanate ligands (5.499<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) . As expected, the Cu(1)⋯Cu(1) separation in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is considerably longer than that typically observed in doubly μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> bridged copper(II) species (5.264(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å)  since the two Cu(II) atoms are located in <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> relative to the 1,3-azido bridge.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: A search in the CCDC data base shows that 2 is the first singly μ1,3-N3 bridged symmetrical, four coordinated, copper(II)-Schiff base dinuclear species . The Cu(1)⋯Cu(1) separation in 2 is 5.789Å and is shorter than that of the earlier reported copper(II) complexes with single μ1,3-N3 bridges (6.086(7)Å)  but is similar to those of other copper(II) complexes with μ1,3-bridging cyanate (5.8Å) and thiocyanate ligands (5.499Å) . As expected, the Cu(1)⋯Cu(1) separation in 2 is considerably longer than that typically observed in doubly μ1,3-N3 bridged copper(II) species (5.264(1)Å)  since the two Cu(II) atoms are located in trans relative to the 1,3-azido bridge.

[(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3)

X-ray crystal structure analysis shows that 3 [Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2]2+ is a doubly μ1,1-azido bridged coordination polymer with μ1,1-azide ions connecting copper centers. The polymer is propagated along the c axis. Along the c axis copper bound Schiff base ligands alternate, related by 2-fold axes. The polymer is composed of vertex sharing defect dicubanes with one vertex unoccupied already seen . Each dicubane is linked to the next via a symmetric double μ1,1-azido bridge link linking Cu(1) to its symmetry equivalent ( ). The bond lengths and angles for 3 are listed in  . However, there are three distinct copper centers. Cu(1) is bound by four azido ligands but its fifth and longest contact is with the Schiff base enolato oxygen atom [O(1)=2.486Å forming a "long bond"]. Cu(2) is chelated by the tridentate NNO Schiff base with its fourth and fifth sites filled by a short bond of a μ1,1-bridging azide and a relatively "long bond" formed by a μ1,1,1-bridging azido ligand. Both five coordinate copper centers are square pyramidal but Cu(1) is more distorted towards trigonal bipyramidal geometry than Cu(2), as reflected in their Addison  parameters 0.22 and 0.03, respectively. Unlike Cu(1) and Cu(2), Cu(3) lies on a center of inversion, and is coordinated solely to azido ligands with typical Jahn-Teller distorted octahedral geometry ( ). The longest Cu-N contacts involves the triply bridging azido nitrogen [N(10)] and its symmetry equivalent. There are two unique double-bridging terminal azido ligands in the defect cubane, one, involving N(7), is significantly asymmetric, with the longer contact (2.025(2)Å) to Cu(3) and the shorter to Cu(1) (1.978(2)Å). The other azido N(13) bridges Cu(2) and Cu(3) in a symmetric fashion (2.031(2), 2.037(2)Å). The double azido bridge which links the cubanes is also symmetric but the Cu(1)-N distances are shorter: 1.990(2)Å to N(1) and 1.988(2)Å to N(4). The one unique triply bridging azido is quite asymmetric in the manner to which it binds to the three copper centers. Its closest contact is with Cu(1) (2.043(3)Å) and its longest contact, rather longer than a conventional bond ("long bond"), is 2.570(3)Å to Cu(2) which is bound by the Schiff base and forms a long axial contact with respect to the square plane defined by the Schiff base and μ1,1-bridging azide N(13). Cu(2) is displaced by only 0.085Å from this plane. In contrast N(1), N(4), N(7) and N(10) which bind Cu(1) cannot effectively be defined as one plane but rather as two, with the plane containing Cu(1), N(1) and N(4) inclined at 17.46° to the plane defined by Cu(1), N(7) and N(10). This also describes the twist of the polymeric bridge as it is propagated along the c axis ( ).

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0140" view="all">There are many hundreds of copper cubane structures in the CSD (version November 2009), but few involve predominantly N-binding ligands. Two structures in the CSD codes IBOBOQ  and RIZPAS  possess a Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> core and BIWVOT  has a Cu<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>O core which is closest to <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. However, this core face-shares with its neighbor defect cubane as opposed to the vertex sharing found in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. The polymer in BIWVOT is propagated by double <ce:italic>end-to-end</ce:italic> azido bridges rather than the double <ce:italic>end-on</ce:italic> bridges as seen in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, which means that the cubane units are closer in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> (3.121<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) than in BIWVOT where the closest bridged Cu⋯Cu contact is 4.438<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: There are many hundreds of copper cubane structures in the CSD (version November 2009), but few involve predominantly N-binding ligands. Two structures in the CSD codes IBOBOQ  and RIZPAS  possess a Cu3N4 core and BIWVOT  has a Cu3N3O core which is closest to 3. However, this core face-shares with its neighbor defect cubane as opposed to the vertex sharing found in 3. The polymer in BIWVOT is propagated by double end-to-end azido bridges rather than the double end-on bridges as seen in 3, which means that the cubane units are closer in 3 (3.121Å) than in BIWVOT where the closest bridged Cu⋯Cu contact is 4.438Å.

elements.clean_text:
Magnetic properties

The thermal variation of the molar magnetic susceptibility per copper(II) dimer times the temperature (χ m T) for compound 2 shows at room temperature a value of ca. 0.50emuKmol-1 ( ). This value is significantly lower than the expected one for two non interacting CuII S =1/2ions (0.75emuKmol-1 for g =2.0). When cooling down the sample, the χ m T product shows a pronounced decrease to reach a plateau of ca. 0.01emuKmol-1 at ca. 50K. Below this temperature χ m T remains constant and almost negligible down to 2K (). This behavior indicates that compound 2 presents a strong antiferromagnetic coupling, as indicated by the low χ m T value at room temperature and by the fact that the χ m T plot shows a pronounced decrease starting above room temperature. As expected, this strong antiferromagnetic coupling leads to an S =0 spin ground state. The very low χ m T value observed at low temperatures comes from the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurity (probably as copper(II) monomers). This strong antiferromagnetic coupling is also confirmed in the thermal variation of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χ m) that shows a broad maximum near room temperature (inset in ). The paramagnetic impurity is also clearly observed as a Curie-type tail at low temperatures.
