elements.clean_text:
This model reproduces very satisfactorily the magnetic data of 2 in the whole temperature range with g =2.240(9), J =-362(2) K =-252(1)cm-1, Nα =220×10-6 emumol-1 and c =0.4(1)% (solid line in ).

As expected, the magnetic coupling is strong and antiferromagnetic, in agreement with the magneto-structural correlations established for azide-bridged copper(II) complexes and with DFT calculations. These calculations show that the μ1,3-N3 bridges give rise to strong antiferromagnetic interactions when the azide bridge connects equatorial positions in a square planar or square pyramidal geometry () . These calculations, performed for an ideal square pyramidal geometry, indicate that, given the structural parameters of 2, the coupling should be very strong and antiferromagnetic, in agreement with the experimental value.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Catalytic studies</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Catalytic properties of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> for alkene oxidations</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0165" view="all">The ability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> to catalyze the oxidation of styrene was investigated using various oxidants including PhIO, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA and O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was found not to be a good oxidant under conditions used here, but the complex showed to be an efficient catalyst for the styrene oxidation when PhIO is the oxidant. In Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, the presence of 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol% <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> catalyze the oxidation of styrene with PhIO to yield 75% conversion in 3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, and 90% conversion in 6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0035"></ce:float-anchor>).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic studies

Catalytic properties of 1 for alkene oxidations

The ability of 1 to catalyze the oxidation of styrene was investigated using various oxidants including PhIO, H2O2, m-CPBA and O2. O2 was found not to be a good oxidant under conditions used here, but the complex showed to be an efficient catalyst for the styrene oxidation when PhIO is the oxidant. In Cl2CH2, the presence of 0.2mol% 1 catalyze the oxidation of styrene with PhIO to yield 75% conversion in 3h, and 90% conversion in 6h ( ).

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0170" view="all">Analysis of the styrene oxidation profiles (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0055"></ce:float-anchor>) shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> presents high selectivity towards the formation of styrene epoxide, yielding 83% of epoxide and 15% benzaldehyde. Addition of a neutral base, either NMO or PNO, has no effect on the styrene conversion or epoxide selectivity. Kinetic profiles show that benzaldehyde is mostly formed during the reaction course of epoxidation and is not due to subsequent oxidation of the styrene epoxide, but results from a reaction that takes place in parallel to styrene epoxidation.  also shows data obtained after a second addition of 500-times excess of styrene-PhIO over the catalyst left in the reaction mixture. The kinetic curves show that the styrene oxidation rate and epoxide selectivity after the second addition are essentially the same as in the first kinetic run. The fact that the catalyst retains its activity after successive additions evidences its robustness, affording turnover numbers as high as 900 (twice the t.o.n. of the first run). However, it must be noted that the electronic spectra taken at the end of the reaction differ from that of the starting complex, suggesting that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a pre-catalyst that transforms into the active species upon reaction with the oxidant, the resting form of which differs from the starting complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Analysis of the styrene oxidation profiles ( ) shows that 1 presents high selectivity towards the formation of styrene epoxide, yielding 83% of epoxide and 15% benzaldehyde. Addition of a neutral base, either NMO or PNO, has no effect on the styrene conversion or epoxide selectivity. Kinetic profiles show that benzaldehyde is mostly formed during the reaction course of epoxidation and is not due to subsequent oxidation of the styrene epoxide, but results from a reaction that takes place in parallel to styrene epoxidation.  also shows data obtained after a second addition of 500-times excess of styrene-PhIO over the catalyst left in the reaction mixture. The kinetic curves show that the styrene oxidation rate and epoxide selectivity after the second addition are essentially the same as in the first kinetic run. The fact that the catalyst retains its activity after successive additions evidences its robustness, affording turnover numbers as high as 900 (twice the t.o.n. of the first run). However, it must be noted that the electronic spectra taken at the end of the reaction differ from that of the starting complex, suggesting that 1 is a pre-catalyst that transforms into the active species upon reaction with the oxidant, the resting form of which differs from the starting complex.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0175" view="all">When H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was used as an oxygen source, the styrene oxidation catalyzed by <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was found to be solvent dependent, being acetone better than Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> or CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN to carry out the catalysis. This is probably due to the formation of 2-hydroxy-2-hydroperoxypropane that stimulates gradual availability of the oxidant, limiting its decomposition . In acetone, catalyst <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> converted 34% of styrene in 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. It is evident from  that between H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and PhIO, the later acts as a better oxidant with respect to both styrene conversion and epoxide selectivity. The lower efficiency of the complex to catalyze the epoxidation of styrene with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> can be attributed to catalyst deactivation in aqueous medium and partial H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> disproportionation. Also in this case, addition of a neutral donor ligand (NMO or PNO) showed no effect on the styrene conversion or epoxide selectivity. When 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol% of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was used, no catalytic effect was observed on the rate of styrene oxidation with <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA at 0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. However, after increasing the proportion of catalyst in the reaction mixture to 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol% (catalyst:styrene:<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1:25:50), styrene was catalytically oxidized by the <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA-<ce:bold>1</ce:bold> system (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0040"></ce:float-anchor>). With this oxidant, it was found that the styrene oxidation in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN gave superior yield in a time shorter than in CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-<ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA system was further explored in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>CN for the other alkenes listed in . As it can be observed, oxidation rates of cyclohexene and <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic>-4-octene are faster than those of styrene and <ce:italic>cis</ce:italic>-stylbene, which indicates that the catalyst favors the oxidation of the more electron rich substrates over the less ones. This result would suggest an electrophilic character for the active site of catalyst. However, given that a similar trend is found for the oxidation of these alkenes with <ce:italic>m</ce:italic>-CPBA alone – although at a much slower rate –, this interpretation should be taken with care.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When H2O2 was used as an oxygen source, the styrene oxidation catalyzed by 1 was found to be solvent dependent, being acetone better than Cl2CH2 or CH3CN to carry out the catalysis. This is probably due to the formation of 2-hydroxy-2-hydroperoxypropane that stimulates gradual availability of the oxidant, limiting its decomposition . In acetone, catalyst 1 converted 34% of styrene in 4h. It is evident from  that between H2O2 and PhIO, the later acts as a better oxidant with respect to both styrene conversion and epoxide selectivity. The lower efficiency of the complex to catalyze the epoxidation of styrene with H2O2 can be attributed to catalyst deactivation in aqueous medium and partial H2O2 disproportionation. Also in this case, addition of a neutral donor ligand (NMO or PNO) showed no effect on the styrene conversion or epoxide selectivity. When 0.2mol% of 1 was used, no catalytic effect was observed on the rate of styrene oxidation with m-CPBA at 0°C. However, after increasing the proportion of catalyst in the reaction mixture to 4mol% (catalyst:styrene:m-CPBA=1:25:50), styrene was catalytically oxidized by the m-CPBA-1 system ( ). With this oxidant, it was found that the styrene oxidation in CH3CN gave superior yield in a time shorter than in CH2Cl2. The 1-m-CPBA system was further explored in CH3CN for the other alkenes listed in . As it can be observed, oxidation rates of cyclohexene and trans-4-octene are faster than those of styrene and cis-stylbene, which indicates that the catalyst favors the oxidation of the more electron rich substrates over the less ones. This result would suggest an electrophilic character for the active site of catalyst. However, given that a similar trend is found for the oxidation of these alkenes with m-CPBA alone - although at a much slower rate -, this interpretation should be taken with care.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0180" view="all">It is interesting to compare the catalytic performance of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> with that of other Co-based systems. Complexes of the Co-salen family have been reported to catalyze the epoxidation of cyclohexene with PhIO in Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> at 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, to yield 66% conversion (t.o.n.<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6.6) in 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . Other Co complexes of the same family were found to yield 35<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol% of styrene epoxide (t.o.n.<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>7) in 3.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h, in DMF and 0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, when H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was used as terminal oxidant . Co-calix  pyrrole complexes were found to catalyze styrene epoxidation by O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/ethylbutyraldehyde with 68% of epoxide formation (t.o.n.<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>68), after 24<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h . In all these systems, the catalysts are used in high proportion and low t.o.n. are achieved. An improved catalytic system for cyclohexene oxidation was obtained with a heterogeneous system: LDH-hosted Co-salen complex, which yields 53% of epoxide (t.o.n.<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>98) using O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>/aldehyde as oxidant .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: It is interesting to compare the catalytic performance of 1 with that of other Co-based systems. Complexes of the Co-salen family have been reported to catalyze the epoxidation of cyclohexene with PhIO in Cl2CH2 at 25°C, to yield 66% conversion (t.o.n.=6.6) in 2h . Other Co complexes of the same family were found to yield 35mol% of styrene epoxide (t.o.n.=7) in 3.5h, in DMF and 0°C, when H2O2 was used as terminal oxidant . Co-calix  pyrrole complexes were found to catalyze styrene epoxidation by O2/ethylbutyraldehyde with 68% of epoxide formation (t.o.n.=68), after 24h . In all these systems, the catalysts are used in high proportion and low t.o.n. are achieved. An improved catalytic system for cyclohexene oxidation was obtained with a heterogeneous system: LDH-hosted Co-salen complex, which yields 53% of epoxide (t.o.n.=98) using O2/aldehyde as oxidant .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0185" view="all">Therefore, although less active for epoxidation of alkenes than Mn catalysts , the high turnover numbers and the retention of activity after successive additions of oxidant, places the catalytic activity of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-PhIO system above those of other cobalt catalysts reported so far for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Therefore, although less active for epoxidation of alkenes than Mn catalysts , the high turnover numbers and the retention of activity after successive additions of oxidant, places the catalytic activity of the 1-PhIO system above those of other cobalt catalysts reported so far for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Catalase-like activity studies for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0190" view="all">The catalase-like function of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> to disproportionate H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> into H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was examined at 0 and 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C by volumetric measurements of evolved dioxygen. The complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was insoluble in water therefore, catalytic activities of the complexes were determined in <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>-dimethylformamide. Experiments were repeated several times to ensure consistency of the results. The time course of the dioxygen evolution is shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0060"></ce:float-anchor>. The reactivity studies indicated that the complex itself is catalytically almost inactive, but the decomposition of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is enhanced in the presence of a base such as 1-methylimidazole (1-MeimH), imidazole (imH) or pyridine (py) because of their strong π-donating ability. However, it is observed that base itself causes only a very slight disproportionation of the peroxide. For <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the dioxygen evolution rate was reached after the reaction was initiated and the evolution profile followed by a short slow period process to finish the reaction. When the catalytic process ceased, the evolved dioxygen gas corresponds to 100% decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, implying that the complex catalysts are efficient towards peroxide dismutation.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Catalase-like activity studies for 2 

The catalase-like function of 2 to disproportionate H2O2 into H2O and O2 was examined at 0 and 25°C by volumetric measurements of evolved dioxygen. The complex 2 was insoluble in water therefore, catalytic activities of the complexes were determined in N,N-dimethylformamide. Experiments were repeated several times to ensure consistency of the results. The time course of the dioxygen evolution is shown in  . The reactivity studies indicated that the complex itself is catalytically almost inactive, but the decomposition of H2O2 is enhanced in the presence of a base such as 1-methylimidazole (1-MeimH), imidazole (imH) or pyridine (py) because of their strong π-donating ability. However, it is observed that base itself causes only a very slight disproportionation of the peroxide. For 2, the dioxygen evolution rate was reached after the reaction was initiated and the evolution profile followed by a short slow period process to finish the reaction. When the catalytic process ceased, the evolved dioxygen gas corresponds to 100% decomposition of hydrogen peroxide, implying that the complex catalysts are efficient towards peroxide dismutation.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0195" view="all">When studied at 0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C the oxygen evolution profile was sigmoidal and evolution ceased in 17<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min. On the other hand, the catalysis became faster and the evolution ceased in 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min at 25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. At this stage the evolved dioxygen corresponded to 100% decomposition of the added hydrogen peroxide (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0065"></ce:float-anchor>). Different concentrations are tested for heterocyclic base and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> to find optimal ratio (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0070"></ce:float-anchor>). By observing the profiles, we can find that the maximum catalytic activities occur near the point where the concentrations of imidazole are equal to that of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. The same result was observed when 1-methylimidazole or pyridine was used instead of imidazole. But it was found that 1-methylimidazole appears to be the most efficient base for peroxide disproportionation. This fact means the catalytic activity of the complex is related with the pKa of the added heterocyclic base, indicating that the ability of 1-methylimidazole for binding proton is larger than that of imidazole and pyridine . This is also consistent with the pKa of pyridine (5.2), imidazole (7.1) and 1-methylimidazole (7.4).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: When studied at 0°C the oxygen evolution profile was sigmoidal and evolution ceased in 17min. On the other hand, the catalysis became faster and the evolution ceased in 8min at 25°C. At this stage the evolved dioxygen corresponded to 100% decomposition of the added hydrogen peroxide ( ). Different concentrations are tested for heterocyclic base and H2O2 to find optimal ratio ( ). By observing the profiles, we can find that the maximum catalytic activities occur near the point where the concentrations of imidazole are equal to that of H2O2. The same result was observed when 1-methylimidazole or pyridine was used instead of imidazole. But it was found that 1-methylimidazole appears to be the most efficient base for peroxide disproportionation. This fact means the catalytic activity of the complex is related with the pKa of the added heterocyclic base, indicating that the ability of 1-methylimidazole for binding proton is larger than that of imidazole and pyridine . This is also consistent with the pKa of pyridine (5.2), imidazole (7.1) and 1-methylimidazole (7.4).

The catalytic activity of haemolysate was investigated in the presence and absence of the complex. The catalase activity of the control group changes significantly in the experimental group but the catalytic degradation of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is inhibited by the complex (). This result may be due to μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-azido bridges of the complex. Because it is known that the activity of catalase is inhibited by several compounds, including its natural substrate, H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (concentrations >0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>M and reaction times >30<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>s), azide, acetic acid, formic acid, fluoride, cyanide, hydroxylamine, carbon monoxide, heavy metals (Cu<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>, Pb<ce:sup loc="post">2+</ce:sup>) and 3-amino-1,2,4-triazine .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
The catalytic results indicate that 2 has reasonably good catalase activity and may be suitable as a functional model for the pseudocatalase enzyme.

Effect of 2 on catalase activity of haemolysate

The effect of 2 on catalase activity of haemolysate to disproportionate H2O2 into H2O and O2 was examined in N,N-dimethylformamide at room temperature. The catalytic activity of haemolysate was investigated in the presence and absence of the complex. The catalase activity of the control group changes significantly in the experimental group but the catalytic degradation of H2O2 is inhibited by the complex (). This result may be due to μ1,3-azido bridges of the complex. Because it is known that the activity of catalase is inhibited by several compounds, including its natural substrate, H2O2 (concentrations >0.1M and reaction times >30s), azide, acetic acid, formic acid, fluoride, cyanide, hydroxylamine, carbon monoxide, heavy metals (Cu2+, Pb2+) and 3-amino-1,2,4-triazine .

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0210" view="all">The interesting aspect of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is that in spite of μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-bridging azido ligand, it exhibits catalytic activity and catalyses the disproportionation of hydrogen peroxide in presence of added base, as observed in the literature . On the other hand, it is found that at pH 7.4 and in presence of excess hydrogen peroxide the catalytic activity of blood haemolysate is inhibited by the complex.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The interesting aspect of 2 is that in spite of μ1,3-bridging azido ligand, it exhibits catalytic activity and catalyses the disproportionation of hydrogen peroxide in presence of added base, as observed in the literature . On the other hand, it is found that at pH 7.4 and in presence of excess hydrogen peroxide the catalytic activity of blood haemolysate is inhibited by the complex.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0215" view="all">Moreover, the effect of complex concentration on the degradation of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> by haemolysate has been investigated. For this purpose the hydrogen peroxide concentration is kept constant and the concentration of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is varied (1–40<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM). It was found that inhibition of blood haemolysate increases with the increasing of the complex concentrations (). Thus, at low complex concentrations the inhibition of haemolysate varies linearly with the complex concentration, but over 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mM complex concentrations, inhibition of blood haemolysate by the complex is increasing slightly.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Moreover, the effect of complex concentration on the degradation of H2O2 by haemolysate has been investigated. For this purpose the hydrogen peroxide concentration is kept constant and the concentration of 2 is varied (1-40mM). It was found that inhibition of blood haemolysate increases with the increasing of the complex concentrations (). Thus, at low complex concentrations the inhibition of haemolysate varies linearly with the complex concentration, but over 5mM complex concentrations, inhibition of blood haemolysate by the complex is increasing slightly.

<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0220" view="all">Three new cobalt(III) and copper(II) complexes, formulated as [Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [Cu<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)].ClO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cu<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>(μ-O<ce:bold>L</ce:bold>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,1,1</ce:inf>-N<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) have been synthesised with the tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand [(1<ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>,3<ce:italic>E</ce:italic>)-3-((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)-1-phenylbut-1-en-1-ol<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:bold>LH</ce:bold>] and azide ions. Interestingly, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is the first dinuclear copper(II) square planar complex with a tridentate Schiff base and a single μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-azido bridge. Another intriguing fact in this complex is the presence of a very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−252(1)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) through the single μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-azido bridge. This value is more than twice the highest value reported to date for a double μ<ce:inf loc="post">1,3</ce:inf>-azido bridged copper(II)-dinuclear compound (<ce:italic>J</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>−105<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>) . Last, but not the least, the high turnover numbers and the retention of activity after successive additions of oxidant, places the catalytic activity of the <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>-PhIO system above those of other cobalt catalysts reported so far for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have shown to have reasonably good catalase activity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Three new cobalt(III) and copper(II) complexes, formulated as [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1), [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)].ClO4 (2) and [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3) have been synthesised with the tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand [(1Z,3E)-3-((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)-1-phenylbut-1-en-1-ol= LH] and azide ions. Interestingly, 2 is the first dinuclear copper(II) square planar complex with a tridentate Schiff base and a single μ1,3-azido bridge. Another intriguing fact in this complex is the presence of a very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (J =-252(1)cm-1) through the single μ1,3-azido bridge. This value is more than twice the highest value reported to date for a double μ1,3-azido bridged copper(II)-dinuclear compound (J =-105cm-1) . Last, but not the least, the high turnover numbers and the retention of activity after successive additions of oxidant, places the catalytic activity of the 1-PhIO system above those of other cobalt catalysts reported so far for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase and 2 have shown to have reasonably good catalase activity.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of [C6H5C(OH)CHC(CH3)NCH2C5H4N] (LH)

The synthesis and characterization of the Schiff base ligand (LH) has been done following the method described in the literature . The 1:1 equimolar condensation of 2-picolylamine and benzoylacetone for 2h in methanolic medium results in a yellow solution. The color indicates the formation of the Schiff base ligand (LH) which was used without further purification. Yield: 0.221g (88%). Anal. Calc. for [C16H16N2O]: C, 76.19; H, 6.35; N, 11.11. Found: C, 76.18; H, 6.31; N, 11.10%.

 Caution! Perchlorate salts and azide derivatives in presence of organic ligands are potentially explosive and should be used in small quantity with much care.

Syntheses of [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1)

The slow addition of 20mL of a yellow methanolic solution of the Schiff base (LH) (0.252g, 1mmol) to 10mL of a methanolic solution of cobalt perchlorate hexahydrate (0.365g, 1mmol) resulted in a dark red solution. This solution was stirred for 15min at room temperature and then followed by the addition of 2mL of an aqueous solution of sodium azide (0.130g, 2mmol). The dark red solution so obtained was gently stirred for 1h at 40°C, resulting in a color change from dark red to dark brown. The dark brown solution was then filtered and kept at room temperature. Brown needle shaped crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction was obtained after one day. The crystals were filtered and air-dried. Yield: 0.314g (86%). Anal. Calc. for [C32H30 Co2N16O2]: C, 48.69; H, 3.80; N, 28.40. Found: C, 48.62; H, 3.77; N, 28.38%.

Syntheses of [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)]⋅ClO4 (2)

Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (0.37g, 1mmol) was dissolved in 10mL of methanol by stirring. It was then followed by the subsequent addition of 20mL of a yellow methanolic solution of LH (0.252g, 1mmol) resulting in a light green solution. While the solution was stirred, 5mL of an aqueous methanolic solution of sodium azide (0.032g, 0.5mmol) were carefully added dropwise to the light green solution to give a dark green solution. Addition of sodium azide was immediately stopped when a small amount of brown colored solid separated. The dark green solution was then filtered and kept in a refrigerator. Brown prismatic crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after three days. Crystals were filtered and air-dried. Yield: 0.303g (82%). Anal. Calc. for [C32H30Cl1Cu2N7O6]: C, 49.79; H, 3.89; N, 12.70. Found: C, 49.78; H, 3.85; N, 12.68%.

Syntheses of [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3)

Copper perchlorate hexahydrate (0.55g, 1.5mmol) was dissolved in 1:1 v/v methanol-acetone mixture (20mL) by vigorous stirring. 10mL of a yellow methanolic solution of the Schiff base (LH) (0.126g, 0.5mmol) were slowly added with stirring to the copper perchlorate hexahydrate solution to produce a bluish green solution. Successive very slow addition of 5mL of an aqueous solution of sodium azide (0.192g, 3mmol) at higher molar ratio compared to that of 2, prevented the precipitation of a brown solid and resulted in a dark green solution that produced a small amount of green solid which redissolved upon complete addition of sodium azide. The obtained dark green solution was then filtered and was kept at room temperature. A dark blue amorphous product was obtained in a much lower yield (compared to that of 2) after a week. Recrystallisation of the dark blue product in 1:1 v/v methanol-acetonitrile mixture resulted in a few blue needle shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction after two weeks. Crystals were filtrated and air-dried. The IR spectra of the amorphous and the crystalline product were almost similar to each other but were not superimposable. Yield: 0.165g (30%). Anal. Calc. for [C32H30Cu5N28O2]: C, 33.20; H, 2.59; N, 33.89. Found: C, 33.18; H, 2.53; N, 33.86%.

cln_elements.clean_text:
UV-Vis spectroscopy

UV-Vis spectra of the ligand and the complexes (1 and 2) have been recorded at 300K in HPLC grade acetonitrile solution but due to the poor solubility of 3 in acetonitrile medium, solid state Nujol mull absorption electronic spectrum was recorded for 3. It has been already reported earlier  that the spectra of the free ligand (LH) shows two intraligand charge transfer (CT) bands at 331 and 248nm whereas the spectra of all three complexes show three different CT bands at 450, 322, 266nm (1), 402, 324, 258nm (2) and 406, 328, 262nm (3). Accordingly in 1, 2 and 3 the bands obtained at 322, 266nm, 324, 258nm and 328, 262nm are assigned to intraligand charge transfer transitions respectively but since the spectrum of the free ligand has no CT bands in the region 402-450nm hence we can conclude that CT bands obtained at 450, 402 and 406nm in 1-3, respectively, are associated to L→M charge transfer transitions. Besides these allowed bands, the three compounds also show much weaker and less well defined broad bands at 630nm (1), 600nm (2) and 634 and 682nm (3) which are assigned to the d-d transitions in the respective complexes. The band at 630nm for 1 is attributed 1 A 1g → 1 T 1g transition for the distorted octahedral cobalt(III) ion, whereas d-d transition at 600nm for 2 is attributed to structurally well characterized square planar copper(II) complexes . Unlike 1 and 2, the two broad d-d bands obtained for 3 are in good agreement with the simultaneous presence of two different coordination environments in the complex. The band at 634nm is associated with a copper(II) center having a distorted octahedral geometry and the d-d transition at 682nm indicates the presence of copper(II) ions residing in a distorted square pyramidal geometry .

Magnetic properties

The thermal variation of the molar magnetic susceptibility per copper(II) dimer times the temperature (χ m T) for compound 2 shows at room temperature a value of ca. 0.50emuKmol-1 ( ). This value is significantly lower than the expected one for two non interacting CuII S =1/2ions (0.75emuKmol-1 for g =2.0). When cooling down the sample, the χ m T product shows a pronounced decrease to reach a plateau of ca. 0.01emuKmol-1 at ca. 50K. Below this temperature χ m T remains constant and almost negligible down to 2K (). This behavior indicates that compound 2 presents a strong antiferromagnetic coupling, as indicated by the low χ m T value at room temperature and by the fact that the χ m T plot shows a pronounced decrease starting above room temperature. As expected, this strong antiferromagnetic coupling leads to an S =0 spin ground state. The very low χ m T value observed at low temperatures comes from the presence of a small amount of paramagnetic impurity (probably as copper(II) monomers). This strong antiferromagnetic coupling is also confirmed in the thermal variation of the molar magnetic susceptibility (χ m) that shows a broad maximum near room temperature (inset in ). The paramagnetic impurity is also clearly observed as a Curie-type tail at low temperatures.

This model reproduces very satisfactorily the magnetic data of 2 in the whole temperature range with g =2.240(9), J =-362(2) K =-252(1)cm-1, Nα =220×10-6 emumol-1 and c =0.4(1)% (solid line in ).

As expected, the magnetic coupling is strong and antiferromagnetic, in agreement with the magneto-structural correlations established for azide-bridged copper(II) complexes and with DFT calculations. These calculations show that the μ1,3-N3 bridges give rise to strong antiferromagnetic interactions when the azide bridge connects equatorial positions in a square planar or square pyramidal geometry () . These calculations, performed for an ideal square pyramidal geometry, indicate that, given the structural parameters of 2, the coupling should be very strong and antiferromagnetic, in agreement with the experimental value.

Catalytic studies

Catalytic properties of 1 for alkene oxidations

The ability of 1 to catalyze the oxidation of styrene was investigated using various oxidants including PhIO, H2O2, m-CPBA and O2. O2 was found not to be a good oxidant under conditions used here, but the complex showed to be an efficient catalyst for the styrene oxidation when PhIO is the oxidant. In Cl2CH2, the presence of 0.2mol% 1 catalyze the oxidation of styrene with PhIO to yield 75% conversion in 3h, and 90% conversion in 6h ( ).

Conclusion

Three new cobalt(III) and copper(II) complexes, formulated as [Co2(L)2(μ1,1-N3)2(N3)2] (1), [Cu2(L)2(μ1,3-N3)].ClO4 (2) and [(μ1,1-N3)2Cu5(μ-OL)2(μ1,1-N3)4(μ1,1,1-N3)2] n  (3) have been synthesised with the tridentate NNO donor Schiff base ligand [(1Z,3E)-3-((pyridin-2-yl)methylimino)-1-phenylbut-1-en-1-ol= LH] and azide ions. Interestingly, 2 is the first dinuclear copper(II) square planar complex with a tridentate Schiff base and a single μ1,3-azido bridge. Another intriguing fact in this complex is the presence of a very strong antiferromagnetic exchange interaction (J =-252(1)cm-1) through the single μ1,3-azido bridge. This value is more than twice the highest value reported to date for a double μ1,3-azido bridged copper(II)-dinuclear compound (J =-105cm-1) . Last, but not the least, the high turnover numbers and the retention of activity after successive additions of oxidant, places the catalytic activity of the 1-PhIO system above those of other cobalt catalysts reported so far for alkene oxidation in homogeneous phase and 2 have shown to have reasonably good catalase activity.
